qas.question: Which steps most closely resembles copy-text editing?
What process is best used when only one manuscript is viable?
What process is best used when there are a number of viable manuscripts available?
The process of selectio does not resemble what type of criticism?
Eclectic criticism is not similar to what type of process?
Which steps do not resemble copy-text editing?
What process is not used when there are a number of viable manuscripts available?
When manuscripts are bad, what process gets used?

context: The process of <b4_0>selectio<b4_0/> resembles <b3_0>eclectic<b3_0/> textual criticism, but applied to a restricted set of hypothetical hyparchetypes. The steps of <a0_0><b5_0>examinatio and emendatio<b5_0/><a0_0/> resemble copy-text editing. In fact, the other techniques can be seen as special cases of stemmatics in which a rigorous family history of the text cannot be determined but only approximated. If it seems that one manuscript is by far the best text, then <a1_0>copy text editing<a1_0/> is appropriate, and if it seems that a group of manuscripts are good, then <a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>eclecticism<b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/> on that group would be proper.
